case_metadata.title: Case 10042: Cardiac Failure in a Young Woman

social_history.other: Nationality may have been a communication barrier

Doctor B.role: Consulting Doctor (Dr. Cabot - derived from text)

turn_1.speaker: Nurse A
turn_1.message: Hello, welcome to the hospital. I'm Nurse [Nurse A's Name]. Can you tell me your name and date of birth, please?
turn_1.source_reference: Medical Text: 'An Austrian seamstress of seventeen entered November 19.'

turn_2.speaker: Patient
turn_2.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - immediately after Nurse A's greeting
turn_2.message: [Patient speaks with a slight accent] My name is [Patient's Name]. I am seventeen years old.
turn_2.source_reference: Medical Text: 'An Austrian seamstress of seventeen...'

turn_3.speaker: Nurse A
turn_3.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - immediately after Patient's response
turn_3.message: Thank you. What brought you in today? I understand you haven't been feeling well.
turn_3.source_reference: Medical Text: 'She was well until three weeks ago, when her legs and arms began to swell.'

turn_4.speaker: Patient
turn_4.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - shortly after Nurse A's question
turn_4.message: Yes, for about three weeks my legs and arms have been swelling.  And for the last day or so, I have a cough and trouble breathing.
turn_4.intention: Explaining chief complaints: swelling and respiratory symptoms.
turn_4.source_reference: Medical Text: 'She was well until three weeks ago, when her legs and arms began to swell. ... Then she began to have cough with sputum and dyspnea.'

turn_5.speaker: Doctor A
turn_5.message: Hello [Patient's Name], I'm Dr. [Doctor A's Name]. Let's take a listen to your lungs.  You mentioned cough and breathing difficulty?
turn_5.intention: Introducing self and beginning physical examination, focusing on respiratory symptoms.
turn_5.source_reference: Medical Text: 'P. E. A well-developed girl with extreme brawny edema of the legs and arms, rapid, grunting and labored respiration, cough...'

turn_6.speaker: Doctor A
turn_6.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - during physical examination, after listening to lungs
turn_6.message: Your breathing is quite labored and rapid. I hear a lot of fluid in your lungs.  And there's significant swelling in your arms and legs, as we can see. Your face looks swollen too.
turn_6.intention: Describing physical exam findings: respiratory distress, pulmonary edema, general edema.
turn_6.source_reference: Medical Text: 'rapid, grunting and labored respiration... bright pinkish-red frothy sputum... Face pale, cyanotic and swollen. Hands very cyanotic. Lungs. Dullness at both bases behind... Very moist bubbling râles... Extreme brawny edema of the lower extremities and arms.'

turn_7.speaker: Doctor A
turn_7.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - after initial physical exam
turn_7.message: Nurse, please get a set of vital signs, including temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure. And let's get a urine sample for analysis and blood work drawn right away.  Stat.
turn_7.intention: Ordering initial investigations: vital signs, urinalysis, blood work.
turn_7.context: Immediate next steps after initial assessment.
turn_7.source_reference: Medical Text: 'T. 99.8°. P. 140. R. 36. Urine. Sp. gr. 1.014. Albumin %%> a few red blood cells and leucocytes, many hyalin, granular and cellular casts. Blood. Hgb. 80%. Leucocytes 27,000; polynuclear leucocytosis.'

turn_8.speaker: Nurse A
turn_8.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - shortly after Doctor A's orders
turn_8.message: Doctor, vital signs are in: Temperature 99.8°F, pulse 140, respirations 36.  Urine and blood samples sent to the lab.

turn_9.speaker: Doctor A
turn_9.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - after receiving vital signs
turn_9.message: [To Patient]  [Patient's Name], your pulse is very fast and your breathing is rapid. We need to help you breathe easier. We're going to do a procedure called venesection to remove some blood to try and relieve some of the fluid overload. It might make you feel a bit better.
turn_9.source_reference: Medical Text: 'Pulses very rapid, of greatly increased tension (180-200, estimated without instrument). ... Venesection was immediately done...'

turn_10.speaker: Doctor A
turn_10.message: Let's remove ten ounces of blood, Nurse.
turn_10.source_reference: Medical Text: 'Venesection was immediately done and ten ounces of blood removed...'

turn_11.speaker: Nurse A
turn_11.message: Ten ounces removed, Doctor. Patient seems a little less distressed, and the lung sounds are slightly clearer now.
turn_11.source_reference: Medical Text: 'ten ounces of blood removed with considerable temporary relief. The râles cleared up to a large extent for a time.'

turn_12.speaker: Doctor A
turn_12.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - after temporary relief from venesection
turn_12.message: Good, some temporary relief. But she's still very restless.  Let's give her a sixth of a grain of morphine to help her rest and calm down.
turn_12.source_reference: Medical Text: 'The patient was so restless that a sixth of a grain of morphia was given.'

turn_13.speaker: Nurse A
turn_13.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - after morphine administration, shortly after
turn_13.message: Doctor, her breathing has become very slow and shallow after the morphine. She's also becoming unresponsive.
turn_13.intention: Reporting adverse reaction to morphine - respiratory depression and unconsciousness.
turn_13.source_reference: Medical Text: 'After this the respirations became very slow, of the air-hunger type, and she was unconscious.'

turn_14.speaker: Doctor A
turn_14.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - immediately after Nurse A's report of deterioration
turn_14.message: Quick, get strophanthin ready for intravenous injection.  Point zero zero zero five milligrams, stat!
turn_14.intention: Ordering strophanthin to counter cardiac issue.
turn_14.source_reference: Medical Text: '.0005 strophanthin was given intravenously without effect.'

turn_15.speaker: Nurse A
turn_15.message: Strophanthin given, Doctor.  But there's no response. She is still unresponsive and her breathing is very shallow.
turn_15.intention: Reporting no effect of strophanthin and continued deterioration.
turn_15.source_reference: Medical Text: '.0005 strophanthin was given intravenously without effect.'

turn_16.speaker: Nurse A
turn_16.message: Doctor, I'm losing a pulse... she's stopped breathing...
turn_16.intention: Reporting cardiac arrest and respiratory arrest.
turn_16.context: Patient experiencing cardiac and respiratory arrest.
turn_16.source_reference: Medical Text: 'Soon after midnight she died.'

turn_17.speaker: Doctor A
turn_17.message: Start chest compressions and call for resuscitation team!  Let's get the crash cart here now!
turn_17.source_reference: Implied from the context of sudden death and standard medical response in such situations. While not explicitly stated, resuscitation attempts are the standard of care.

turn_18.speaker: Doctor A
turn_18.message: Continue compressions, check rhythm, administer epinephrine!  Are we getting any response?
turn_18.intention: Directing resuscitation efforts - CPR and ACLS protocols.
turn_18.source_reference: Implied from the context of cardiac arrest and standard ACLS protocols.  While not explicitly stated, these are standard procedures in cardiac arrest.

turn_19.speaker: Nurse A
turn_19.message: No pulse, no respirations, pupils are fixed and dilated.  No response after several rounds of epinephrine and compressions, Doctor.
turn_19.source_reference: Medical Text: 'Soon after midnight she died.' - Implies unsuccessful resuscitation.

turn_20.speaker: Doctor A
turn_20.timestamp: Admission - November 19th - after confirming unsuccessful resuscitation
turn_20.message: Time of death, midnight [or shortly after midnight].  Let's note the time and circumstances.
turn_20.intention: Pronouncing death and documenting time of death.
turn_20.source_reference: Medical Text: 'Soon after midnight she died.'

turn_21.speaker: Doctor B
turn_21.message: Now and then in a young or middle-aged woman we see a case like this—cardiac failure without an identifiable cardiac lesion in life, but showing fibrous myocarditis at necropsy. My guess is that it was the thrombi and their results rather than the myocarditis that produced most of the physical signs here.
turn_21.intention: Providing expert opinion and summarizing case findings (Epicrisis).
turn_21.source_reference: Medical Text: 'EPICRISIS (DR. CABOT) ... My guess is that it was the thrombi and their results rather than the myocarditis that produced most of the physical signs here.'

turn_22.speaker: Doctor C
turn_22.message: The anatomical findings are consistent with subacute glomerulonephritis, hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart, and chronic passive congestion. We also found hydropericardium, hydrothorax, slight ascites, and edema of the lower extremities.  Kidneys showed congested glomeruli and a reduced cortex. The heart showed slight hypertrophy and dilatation.  Culture from heart blood yielded streptococci.
turn_22.intention: Reporting anatomical diagnosis based on necropsy findings.
turn_22.source_reference: Medical Text: 'ANATOMICAL DIAGNOSIS 1. Primary fatal lesion Subacute glomerulonephritis. # 2. Secondary Or Terminal Lesions Hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart. Chronic passive congestion, general. Hydropericardium. Hydrothorax. Slight ascites. Edema of the lower extremities... The combined weight of the kidneys was 250 grams... The section surfaces showed congestion and the glomeruli generally were very prominent... The heart weighed 280 grams, slight hypertrophy. The cavities showed moderate dilatation... The culture from the heart blood yielded streptococci.'

presentation.chief_complaint: Swelling of legs and arms, cough, and dyspnea.
presentation.history_of_present_illness: Patient was well until three weeks prior to admission when legs and arms began to swell. Cough and dyspnea started the day before admission.
presentation.physical_exam: Well-developed girl with extreme brawny edema of legs and arms, rapid, grunting, labored respiration, cough with pinkish-red frothy sputum, cyanotic and swollen face and hands, dullness at lung bases, moist bubbling râles, rapid heart rate, enlarged liver, increased pulse tension.

initial.blood_pressure: Estimated very high tension (not instrument recorded)

procedures.description: Sixth of a grain of morphine given.

procedures.time: After morphine induced respiratory depression and unconsciousness

procedures.description: CPR and ACLS likely attempted (though not explicitly detailed).

timeline_events.event: Onset of leg and arm swelling.
Onset of cough with sputum and dyspnea.

final_diagnoses: Hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart (Anatomical & Dr. Cabot's Diagnosis)
Chronic passive congestion, general (Anatomical & Dr. Cabot's Diagnosis)
Acute pulmonary edema (Clinical Diagnosis - Hospital Record)
General passive congestion (Clinical Diagnosis - Hospital Record)
Fibrous myocarditis (Necropsy finding - Dr. Cabot's interpretation)
